description: Flash floods are sudden and intense floods caused by heavy rainfall, dam breaks, or rapid snowmelt. They can occur within minutes and are extremely dangerous.
tips: Immediately seek higher ground if you receive a flood alert or hear thunderous sounds of rushing water.
Never walk or drive through floodwaters. Six inches of water can knock you over, and one foot can sweep away your car.
Keep an emergency bag ready containing water, non-perishable food, flashlight, batteries, first aid kit, essential meds, and dry clothing.
Install water alarms in basements and flood-prone areas, and invest in sump pumps with battery backups.
Reinforce basement walls and seal cracks to prevent water seepage.
Create a family evacuation plan with designated meeting spots and communication backups.
Safeguard important documents in waterproof bags and also store them digitally in cloud services.
Participate in flood drills organized by the community and encourage neighbors to join for greater preparedness.

description: Droughts are prolonged periods of low rainfall, resulting in water shortages, crop failures, and increased fire risk.
tips: Turn off taps when not in use, fix all leaks promptly, and use low-flow fixtures to save water.
Reuse water from cooking or cleaning for irrigation where safe.
Plant native and drought-resistant vegetation to reduce water demand.
Mulch garden beds to retain soil moisture and reduce evaporation.
Practice dry farming techniques such as deep tilling and drip irrigation.
Encourage community rainwater harvesting initiatives using storage tanks and cisterns.
Limit lawn irrigation to early morning or late evening to minimize evaporation.
Stock up on potable water for all family members, including pets, for at least two weeks.

description: Hurricanes are massive tropical storms with powerful winds, heavy rain, and storm surges that cause flooding and structural damage.
tips: Secure all outdoor furniture, trash bins, and loose objects that can become projectiles in high winds.
Stockpile at least three days’ worth of food, water, prescription drugs, hygiene supplies, and pet food.
Review your insurance policies and photograph your property before the storm hits.
Seal gaps in roofs, doors, and windows with weatherproofing materials.
Keep a paper list of emergency contact numbers in case phones are inoperable.
Evacuate immediately if ordered, and let someone know your destination and ETA.
Stay indoors in a small, windowless room during the storm and monitor updates via battery-powered radio.
Do not use generators indoors to avoid carbon monoxide poisoning.

description: Heatwaves are prolonged periods of excessive heat that pose risks to human health, especially for the elderly, children, and those with chronic illnesses.
tips: Schedule outdoor work or activities for early morning or late evening.
Stay in shaded or air-conditioned environments; use fans and wet cloths to cool the body.
Wear light, loose-fitting, and breathable clothing—preferably cotton or linen.
Check the heat index before going outdoors and avoid unnecessary exposure during peak hours.
Drink water every 15–30 minutes even if not thirsty. Avoid alcohol, coffee, and sugary drinks.
Use sunblock with SPF 30+ and wear wide-brimmed hats and sunglasses.
Check on elderly neighbors, babies, and pets frequently.
Learn symptoms of heat stroke and act immediately: confusion, dry skin, rapid pulse—seek medical help.

description: Wildfires are uncontrolled fires that rapidly spread through forests, grasslands, and urban areas, often triggered by drought and extreme heat.
tips: Create a defensible space of at least 30 feet around your home by removing dry leaves, twigs, and flammable vegetation.
Install mesh screens on vents to prevent embers from entering buildings.
Keep flammable items such as firewood, propane tanks, and outdoor furniture away from your home walls.
Prepare an evacuation plan and keep your car fueled, with a go-bag always ready.
Stay informed through official alerts and be ready to evacuate early.
Wear N95 masks to protect from smoke inhalation during nearby fires.
Use fire-resistant landscaping (hardscaping) and materials in home construction where possible.
Practice fire drills with family and discuss different escape routes.

description: Glacial lake outburst floods occur when natural dams holding glacial meltwater burst, sending massive volumes of water downstream unexpectedly.
tips: Monitor glacial lake conditions through satellite maps or local agencies in mountainous regions.
Avoid camping, hiking, or building near glacial lakes or flood-prone valleys.
Support installation of early warning systems and sirens in vulnerable areas.
Learn the local evacuation routes and rehearse them with your group before hiking.
Work with communities to create disaster preparedness plans for glacial flood zones.
Raise awareness in schools and tour groups about GLOF dangers and signs.
Advocate for responsible glacial monitoring and dam reinforcement programs.
Do not cross bridges or riverbanks when there's visible water-level surges.

description: Sea level rise due to melting polar ice and thermal expansion threatens coastal communities with long-term flooding and saltwater intrusion.
tips: Avoid long-term property investments in low-lying coastal zones unless they are climate-adapted.
Build on elevated foundations or use floating structures where practical.
Promote and participate in coastal mangrove reforestation which helps buffer storm surges.
Install tide barriers or deploy sandbags during storm tides or king tides.
Have a long-term relocation plan if residing in vulnerable coastal communities.
Test drinking water sources regularly for saltwater contamination.
Promote resilient urban planning that includes raised roads and water drainage upgrades.
Support climate adaptation and advocacy groups for coastal resilience.

description: Severe storms, including tornadoes, derechos, and hailstorms, bring destructive winds, lightning, and structural damage over wide areas.
tips: Identify and prepare a storm shelter in your home, ideally an interior room with no windows.
Secure or bring indoors outdoor objects like bicycles, trash bins, and furniture.
Stay tuned to emergency weather alerts on NOAA radio or mobile apps.
Unplug electronics to prevent damage from lightning surges.
Avoid using corded phones or plumbing during lightning storms.
Protect your windows with storm shutters or thick plywood.
Practice storm drills with your family and teach children what to do if a warning is issued.
Document damages immediately after the storm and contact your insurance provider.

description: Island submergence is the gradual or sudden sinking of low-lying islands due to rising sea levels, coastal erosion, and land subsidence. It endangers the habitat, livelihoods, and cultures of island communities.
tips: Advocate for global climate action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions driving sea level rise.
Strengthen coastal defenses with sea walls, breakwaters, and natural buffers like mangroves and coral reefs.
Elevate homes on stilts or floating foundations where feasible.
Avoid construction near shorelines or areas with visible coastal erosion.
Promote and participate in island community relocation planning and international climate adaptation programs.
Implement sustainable tourism and fishing practices to preserve natural coastal resilience.
Educate community members about evacuation procedures and long-term adaptation options.
Support research and monitoring of local land elevation and sea level trends.
